awd_titl_txt: EFRI 2-DARE:  2D Crystals formed by Activated Atomic Layer Deposition
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical: Transition metal chalcogenides (TMCs) crystallize as two-dimensional sheets of atoms, giving them unusual electronic properties that can be varied by changing the number, arrangement and compositions of the layers. The adjustment of these parameters provides manufacturing challenges that must be overcome to realize potential applications in electronics, photonics and related technologies. The project will research new deposition and processing methods for novel thin film and superconducting devices. This research will enable atomic level film formation at low temperatures that are compatible with low-cost glass and plastic substrates. Techniques to integrate metal contact layers and dielectric films with TMCs to produe working devices will also be researched.  The project will support the research of five graduate students and summer research opportunities for undergraduates and high school students from underrepresented groups and economically challenged regions of Pennsylvania.  Undergraduates will also participate in the project as part of their senior capstone engineering design project organized through the Learning Factory at Penn State.

Technical: This EFRI 2-DARE project is aimed at the development of new synthetic routes and integration strategies for monolayer and multilayer transition metal chalcogenides (TMCs) to enable discovery of fundamental structure-property relationships, the exploration of novel physical phenomena, and the creation of new thin film and superconducting device technologies.  An activated atomic layer deposition (ALD) process for WSe2, FeSe, NbSe2 and related 2D materials will be developed that incorporates thermal and plasma sources to promote precursor decomposition, thereby enabling reduced substrate temperatures that are needed for deposition and dielectric/metal integration on van der Waals surfaces. Epitaxial templating and substrate patterning will be used to control nucleation and promote in-plane forces to induce self-assembly of 2D islands over large areas. In-situ diagnostics will be used to provide insights into the ALD chemistry. Ultra-high resolution aberration-corrected (scanning) transmission electron microscopy ((S)TEM) imaging and related spectroscopy techniques will enable direct imaging and chemical characterization of defects in monolayer and multilayer films, providing information not always accessible by conventional TEM. Device fabrication processes will be developed to enable detailed studies of electrical transport and superconductivity in TMCs. Gated current-voltage measurements, Hall-effect, and quasi-static capacitance-voltage measurements will be used to characterize the transport properties of WSe2 and WS2 thin film devices. Superconductivity in gated FeSe and NbSe2 structures will also be examined to seek high-temperature and unconventional superconductivity.
org_div_long_name: Office of Emerging Frontiers in Research and Innovation (EFRI)

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:  The project was aimed at the development of foundational synthesis and processing knowledge for ultra-thin two-dimensional layered chalcogenide (2DLC) semiconductors for device applications in flexible electronics and related technologies. Two materials systems were investigated: semiconducting transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) which includes WSe2, MoS2 and WS2 and the group III-chalcogenides, specifically In2Se3 which is a ferroelectric semiconductor. Metalorganic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD) was used for epitaxial growth of 2DLC films while plasma-enhanced atomic layer deposition (PEALD) was employed for growth at reduced temperatures which is critical for heat-sensitive substrates and pre-processed devices. Fundamental studies of the MOCVD growth of TMDs on various substrates highlighted the important role of surface diffusion and substrate defects on the orientation and growth of monolayers. Ultra-high-resolution transmission electron microscopy and related spectroscopy techniques were used to image and chemically characterize monolayer TMDs grown by MOCVD providing insights into the type and density of defects and grain boundaries in the films. Methods were developed to enable nucleation and low temperature film deposition on TMD surfaces via PEALD which is critical for the integration of dielectrics and surface passivation layers.  Techniques to reduce the contact resistance of metals on TMD surfaces via controlled etching were demonstrated. Finally, thin film transistors were fabricated using TMDs grown at low temperature and exfoliated from bulk crystals and transferred to flexible substrates. Stable and reproducible device performance was demonstrated after multiple cycles of flexing demonstrating the potential of employing 2DLC-based devices in flexible electronics. The low temperature epitaxial growth and transport properties of In2Se3 thin films were also investigated for possible ferroelectric field-effect device applications.

Broader Impact:  The synthesis and processing strategies developed in this project directly impact emerging device applications for 2DLCs in future generation 3D integrated circuits and flexible electronics. The project provided full or partial financial support for 7 graduate students pursuing their Ph.D. degrees in Materials Science and Engineering, Electrical Engineering and Physics. Supplemental funding through the EFRI Research and Mentoring (REM) program enabled multiple undergraduate students to participate in research and professional development activities each year. A total of 31 undergraduate students participated in the REM program comprising a diverse cohort which included 21 females, 9 underrepresented minorities and 1 military veteran. A training program for graduate student mentors was implemented to enhance the mentor-mentee experience. In addition to working on research, the undergraduates also received training on oral presentation skills, poster preparation, research ethics, formal and informal communication strategies and career development. The undergraduates presented the results of their research projects at an on-campus symposium at the end of summer and at the annual Emerging Researchers National (ERN) Conference. 


Last Modified: 07/31/2020
Modified by: Joan Redwing
